[[Frank Broyles]] }} The '''1977 Liberty Bowl''' was a postseason [[bowl game]] that took place on December 19, 1977. [[1977 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|Nebraska]] beat [[1977 North Carolina Tar Heels football team|North Carolina]], 21–17. https://www.huskermax.com/games/1977/libertyrecap.htmlhttp://www.huskers.com/ViewArticle.dbml?ATCLID=146 ==Scoring summary== *North Carolina - Brooks Williams 12 pass from Matt Kupec (Tom Biddle kick), 13:52 *Nebraska - Dodie Donnell 15 run (Billy Todd kick), 11:00 *North Carolina - Bob Loomis 10 pass from Kupec (Biddle kick), 3:11 *North Carolina - FG Biddle 47, 4:17 *Nebraska - Curtis Craig 10 pass from Randy Garcia (Todd kick), 10:51 *Nebraska - Tim Smith 34 pass from Garcia (Todd kick), 3:16 ==References== {{reflist}} {{Liberty Bowl navbox}} {{Nebraska Cornhuskers bowl game navbox}} {{North Carolina Tar Heels bowl game navbox}} [[Category:1977–78 NCAA football bowl games|Liberty Bowl]] [[Category:Liberty Bowl]] [[Category:Nebraska Cornhuskers football bowl games]] [[Category:North Carolina Tar Heels football bowl games]] [[Category:1977 in sports in Tennessee|Liberty Bowl]] {{US-sport-stub}}

The '''2013 [[IS Open]]''' was a professional [[tennis]] tournament being played on [[Tennis court#Hard courts|hard courts]]. It was the first edition and only edition of the tournament which was part of the [[2013 ATP Challenger Tour]]. It is taking place in [[São Paulo]], [[Brazil]] between 30 September and 6 October 2013.

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Use British English|date=February 2016}} '''Broad''' (first name and dates unknown) was an English [[cricket]]er who played for [[Addington Cricket Club|Addington]] and [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] during the 1740s.
==Career== Broad is mentioned in reports from 1745 to 1750. The first was his appearance for [[Robert Colchin|Long Robin's XI]] v [[Richard Newland (cricketer)|R Newland's XI]] at the [[Artillery Ground]] on Wednesday, 26 June 1745, his team winning by over 70 runs.<ref name=ASW>[[F S Ashley-Cooper]], ''At the Sign of the Wicket: Cricket 1742-1751'', ''Cricket'' Magazine, 1900</ref>
He is known to have played in two matches in 1747. On Thursday, 9 July, he was a member of [[William Hodsoll|W Hodsoll's XI]] versus Long Robin's XI and on Monday, 31 August, he was in the [[All-England Eleven|All-England]] team that played [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]].<ref name=ASW/> The last known mention of Broad is in the Kent v Surrey match at [[Dartford Brent]] on Friday, 6 July 1750.<ref name=ASW/>
As Broad had established his reputation by 1745, he must have been active for some years previously. His career possibly began in the 1730s and continued into the 1750s. Very few players were mentioned by name in contemporary reports.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121010153248/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1741.html From Lads to Lord's]
==Further reading== * [[F S Ashley-Cooper]], ''At the Sign of the Wicket: Cricket 1742-1751'', ''Cricket'' Magazine, 1900 * [[G B Buckley]], ''Fresh Light on 18th Century Cricket'', Cotterell, 1935 * [[Timothy J McCann]], ''Sussex Cricket in the Eighteenth Century'', Sussex Record Society, 2004 * [[H T Waghorn]], ''Cricket Scores, Notes, etc. (1730-1773)'', Blackwood, 1899 * [[H T Waghorn]], ''The Dawn of Cricket'', Electric Press, 1906
{{DEFAULTSORT:Broad}} [[Category:English cricketers]] [[Category:English cricketers of 1701 to 1786]] [[Category:Surrey cricketers]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]] [[Category:Non-international England cricketers]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox GAA tournament | name = Cork Senior Hurling Championship | currentlyrunning = [[2018 Cork Senior Hurling Championship]] | image = |250px | caption = | irish = Craobh Iomána Sinsearach Chorcaí | code = [[Hurling]] | founded = {{Start date and age|df=yes|1887}} | region = [[File:Colours of Cork.svg|20px|border]] [[Cork GAA|Cork]] | trophy = Seán Óg Murphy Cup | teams = 26 | title holders = [[File:Colours of Cork.svg|20px|border]] [[Imokilly GAA|Imokilly]] | currentordinal = 4 | super = th | most titles = [[File:Colours of Kerry.svg|20px|border]] [[Blackrock GAA|Blackrock]] | mostordinal = 32 | sponsors = ''[[Evening Echo]]'' | tv = [[TG4]] | motto = | website = [http://www.gaacork.ie/ Cork GAA] }} The '''Cork Senior Hurling Championship''' (known for sponsorship reasons as the '''''Evening Echo'' Cork County Senior Hurling Championship''') is an annual [[hurling]] competition organised by the [[Cork GAA|Cork County Board]] of the [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] since 1887 for the top hurling teams in the [[County Cork|county of Cork]] in [[Ireland]].
The series of games are played during the summer and autumn months with the county final currently being played at [[Páirc Uí Chaoimh]] in October. The prize for the winning team is the [[Seán Óg Murphy Cup]]. Initially played as a knock-out competition, the championship currently uses a [[Double-elimination tournament|double elimination format]] whereby each team is guaranteed at least two games.
The Cork County Championship is an integral part of the wider [[Munster Senior Club Hurling Championship]]. The winners of the Cork county final join the champions of the other four hurling counties to contest the provincial championship.
Twenty-six teams currently participate in the Cork County Championship. The title has been won at least once by nineteen different teams. The all-time record-holders are [[Blackrock GAA|Blackrock]], who have led the roll of honour since the championship began and have won a total of 32 titles.
[[Imokilly GAA|Imokilly]] are the [[2018 Cork Senior Hurling Championship|title-holders]] after defeating [[Midleton GAA|Midleton]] by 4-19 to 1-18 in the 2018 championship final.
==History== ===Beginnings=== [[File:The Burning of Cork (9713428703).jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|Civil unrest following the burning of Cork during the War of Independence lead to the 1921 championship being cancelled.]] Following the foundation of the [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] in 1884, new rules for [[Gaelic football]] and [[hurling]] were drawn up and published in the ''[[United Irishman (1848 newspaper)|United Irishman]]'' newspaper. In 1886, county committees were established, with the [[Cork GAA|Cork County Board]] affiliating on 19 December 1886. The [[1887 Cork Senior Hurling Championship|inaugural championship]] was played during the summer of 1887, however, the final stages ended in disarray with no final being played. In spite of this, [[Blackrock GAA|Cork Nationals]] were subsequently declared the champions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/histrionics-a-founding-aspect-to-a-rivalry-that-has-real-history-but-least-we-can-expect-a-game-now-1.634844|title=Histrionics a founding aspect to a rivalry that has real history, but least we can expect a game now|publisher=Irish Times|date=7 August 2010|accessdate=10 November 2017|first=|last=}}</ref> Since then the championship title has been awarded every year except on two occasions. A delay in the [[1904 Cork Senior Hurling Championship|1904 championship]] meant that the [[1905 Cork Senior Hurling Championship|1905 championship]] never took place. Civil unrest following the [[burning of Cork]] at the height of the [[Irish War of Independence|War of Independence]] resulted in the 1921 championship being cancelled.
===Team dominance===
Since the beginning the championship has been dominated by [[Blackrock GAA|Blackrock]], [[St. Finbarr's GAA|St. Finbarr's]] and [[Glen Rovers GAA|Glen Rovers]] who are collectively known as the "big three".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-games/hurling/tradition-still-counts-for-a-lot-in-corks-hurling-heart-36249223.html|title=Tradition still counts for a lot in Cork's hurling heart|publisher=Irish Independent|date=22 October 2017|accessdate=5 December 2017|first=Dermot|last=Crowe}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/gaelic-games/cork-hurlers-the-rebels-in-need-of-a-new-uprising-1.2569746|title=Cork hurlers – the Rebels in need of a new uprising|publisher=Irish Times|date=12 March 2016|accessdate=5 December 2017|first=Keith|last=Duggan}}</ref> They have won a combined total of 84 championship titles. Blackrock dominated the first thirty years of the championship, winning 15 titles between 1887 and 1920. It was during this time that the county championship earned the nickname of the "little [[All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship|All-Ireland]]" due to its competitive nature. St. Finbarr's, after making a breakthrough in the early years of the 20th century, were the team of the decade for the 1920s before regularly claiming championship titles in each of the decades that followed. [[Glen Rovers GAA|Glen Rovers]] made their own breakthrough with a first championship in 1934 and were the dominant club from then until the 1960s. Between 1971 and 1982, the "big three" shared every available championship title. Their rivalry reached its peak in 1977 when a record attendance of 34,151 saw St. Finbarr's defeat Glen Rovers in the championship decider.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/sport/gaa/crowded-house-the-ingredients-for-a-packed-pairc-ui-chaoimh-opening-461043.html|title=Crowded house: The ingredients for a packed Páirc Uí Chaoimh opening|publisher=Irish Examiner|date=17 October 2017|accessdate=5 December 2017|first=Michael|last=Moynihan}}</ref>
Since that zenith the "big three" have only claimed two titles in each of the decades from 1990 to 2017 as the power base of Cork hurling has moved from the city to the county with several clubs making significant breakthroughs and impacts on the championship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/sport/columnists/michael-moynihan/a-different-demographic-the-changing-face-of-cork-hurling-242478.html|title=A different demographic: the changing face of Cork hurling|publisher=Irish Examiner|date=10 September 2013|accessdate=5 December 2017|first=Michael|last=Moynihan}}</ref> In 1983 [[Midleton GAA|Midleton]] broke the decade-long hegemony and went on to claim five championships over a thirty-year period to 2013. In 1990 [[Na Piarsaigh GAA|Na Piarsaigh]] became the first city club outside of the "big three" since [[Redmonds GAA|Redmonds]] in 1917 to claim the championship. They added two more titles in 1995 and 2004. [[Erin's Own GAA (Cork)|Erin's Own]] also added their name to the roll of honour in 1992 before winning further titles in 2006 and 2007. The mid nineties saw the rise of the divisional sides, with [[Carbery GAA|Carbery]], [[Avondhu GAA|Avondhu]] and [[Imokilly GAA|Imokilly]] claiming four championship titles between 1994 and 1998. The success of [[Newtownshandrum GAA|Newtownshandrum]] between 2000 and 2009 also highlighted the changing demographics of Cork hurling as the tiny parish of 800 people won four championships during that decade. [[Sarsfields GAA (Cork)|Sarsfields]], although close in proximity to the city but based in the [[East Cork]] division, ended a 51-year famine in 2008 by claiming their third championship title ever. Between 2008 and 2015 they appeared in seven finals and won four titles. The East Cork village of [[Carrigtwohill GAA|Carrigtwohill]] ended a 93-wait for their second championship title in 2011.
In recent decades many rural and city-based clubs have also contested championship deciders without making a successful breakthrough. These include [[Ballyhea GAA|Ballyhea]], [[Cloyne GAA|Cloyne]], [[Bride Rovers GAA|Bride Rovers]] and [[Bishopstown GAA|Bishopstown]]. Educational institutions like [[UCC GAA|University College Cork]] and [[CIT GAA|Cork Institute of Technology]] have also appeared in finals.
===Formats used===
22 teams entered the inaugural championship in 1887 and a [[Single elimination tournament|single elimination format]] was used. Each team was afforded only one defeat before being eliminated from the championship. The creation of the divisions in the 1920s added a new dimension to the championship. These divisional teams, which were composed of [[Cork Junior Hurling Championship|junior]] and [[Cork Intermediate Hurling Championship|intermediate]] players, competed in a preliminary section with the two winning teams advancing to the championship proper which retained its single elimination format. The introduction of a "back door" system at inter-county level in the [[All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship|All-Ireland Championship]] in 1997 lead to the idea of introducing a second chance for defeated teams at county level. In the twenty-year period from the late 1990s to 2017, the championship underwent a number of format changes. The provision of a second chance for defeated teams was later expanded to allow teams the opportunity of being defeated twice and still remain in the championship. The splitting of the intermediate grade in two resulted in the introduction of relegation in 2006, with [[Delaney Rovers GAA|Delaney Rovers]] becoming the first team to be relegated that year. Prior to this teams were allowed to decide for themselves if they wanted to regrade or retain their senior status. In 2015 the championship once again reverted to a [[Double elimination tournament|double elimination format]].
==The championship==
===Overview===
The Cork County Championship is a [[double elimination tournament]]. Each team is afforded two defeats before being eliminated from the championship. Pairings for matches are drawn at random and there is no [[Seed (sports)|seeding]].
Each match is played as a single leg. If a match is drawn there is a period of [[extra time]], however, if both sides are still level at the end of extra time a replay takes place and so on until a winner is found.
===Format=== ====Divisional and college section====
'''Round 1:''' Eight teams contest this round. The four winning teams advance to Round 2. The four losing teams are eliminated from the championship.
'''Round 2:''' Four teams contest this round. The two winning teams advance to Round 3 of the championship proper. The two losing teams are eliminated from the championship.
====Club section====
'''Round 1:''' 18 teams contest this round. The nine losing teams advance to Round 2. The nine winning teams advance to Round 3.
'''Round 2:''' The 9 losing teams from Round 1 contest this round. The four winning teams advance to Round 3. The four losing teams are eliminated from the championship. One team will receive a bye to Round 3.
'''Round 3:''' The 9 winning teams from Round 1, the 4 winning teams from Round 2, the bye team and the 2 divisional teams contest this round. The 8 winning teams advance to the Quarter-finals. The 8 losing teams are eliminated from the championship.
'''Quarter-finals:''' 8 teams contest this round. The 4 winning teams advance to the Semi-finals. The 4 losing teams are eliminated from the championship.
'''Semi-finals:''' 4 teams contest this round. The 2 winning teams advance to the Semi-finals. The 2 losing teams are eliminated from the championship.
'''Final:''' The final is contested by the two semi-final winners.
===Participating teams===
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Team ! Location ! Colours |- |[[Avondhu GAA|Avondhu]] |North Cork |Black and yellow |- |[[Ballyhea GAA|Ballyhea]] |[[Ballyhea]] |Black and white |- |[[Ballymartle GAA|Ballymartle]] |[[Riverstick]] |Green and yellow |- |[[Bandon GAA|Bandon]] |[[Bandon GAA|Bandon]] |White and yellow |- |[[Bishopstown GAA|Bishopstown]] |[[Bishopstown]] |Maroon and white |- |[[Blackrock GAA|Blackrock]] |[[Blackrock, Cork|Blackrock]] |Green and gold |- |[[Bride Rovers GAA|Bride Rovers]] |[[Rathcormac]] |Green, white and gold |- |[[Carbery GAA|Carbery]] |[[Barony of Carbery|West Cork]] |Purple and yellow |- |[[Carrigdhoun GAA|Carrigdhoun]] |Southeast Cork |Red and white |- |[[Carrigtwohill GAA|Carrigtwohill]] |[[Carrigtwohill]] |Blue and yellow |- |[[CIT GAA|Cork Institute of Technology]] |[[Bishopstown]] |Red and white |- |[[Douglas GAA|Douglas]] |[[Douglas, Cork|Douglas]] |Green, black and white |- |[[Duhallow GAA|Duhallow]] |[[Duhallow|Northwest Cork]] |Orange and black |- |[[Erin's Own GAA (Cork)|Erin's Own]] |[[Glounthaune]] |Blue and red |- |[[Glen Rovers GAA|Glen Rovers]] |[[Blackpool, Cork|Blackpool]] |Green, black and yellow |- |[[Imokilly GAA|Imokilly]] |[[East Cork]] |Red and white |- |[[Kanturk GAA|Kanturk]] |[[Kanturk]] |Green and white |- |[[Killeagh GAA|Killeagh]] |[[Killeagh]] |Green and white |- |[[Midleton GAA|Midleton]] |[[Midleton]] |Black and white |- |[[Muskerry GAA|Muskerry]] |[[Muskerry|Mid Cork]] |Green and white |- |[[Na Piarsaigh GAA|Na Piarsaigh]] |Fairhill |Black and yellow |- |[[Newcestown GAA|Newcestown]] |[[Newcestown]] |Red and yellow |- |[[Newtownshandrum GAA|Newtownshandrum]] |[[Newtownshandrum]] |Green and yellow |- |[[Sarsfields GAA (Cork)|Sarsfields]] |[[Glanmire]] |Blue, white and black |- |[[St. Finbarr's GAA|St. Finbarr's]] |[[Togher, Cork|Togher]] |Blue and yellow |- |[[UCC GAA|University College Cork]] |[[Cork (city)|Western Road]] |Red and black |}
==Sponsorship==
Since 2005 the Cork County Championship has been sponsored by the ''[[Evening Echo]]''. The competition was previously sponsored by [[Permanent TSB|TSB Bank]].
==Qualification for subsequent competitions==
The Cork Senior Hurling Championship winners qualify for the subsequent [[Munster Senior Club Hurling Championship]]. This place is reserved for club teams only as divisional and amalgamated teams are not allowed in the provincial championship. If a divisional side wins the Cork Championship then the runners-up qualify for the Munster Championship. This has occurred on five occasions. If two divisional sides qualify for the final then the provincial championship place is given to one of the defeated semi-finalists. This occurred in 1996 when [[Na Piarsaigh GAA|Na Piarsaigh]] represented Cork due to [[Avondhu GAA|Avondhu]] and [[Imokilly GAA|Imokilly]] contesting the final.
==Venues== ===Early rounds=== [[File:Páirc Uí Chaoimh.jpg|thumb|Since 2017 the county final has been held at [[Páirc Uí Chaoimh]], on the site of the previous stadium which hosted it from 1976 to 2014.]] Fixtures in the opening rounds of the championship are usually played at a neutral venue that is deemed halfway between the participating teams. Some of the more common venues include [[Mallow GAA|Mallow GAA Complex]], [[Valley Rovers GAA|Brinny Sportsfield]], [[Aghabullogue GAA|Coachford Pitch]] and [[Midleton GAA|Clonmult Memorial Park]]. All games from Round 4 onward are played at either [[Páirc Uí Rinn]] or [[Páirc Uí Chaoimh]].
=== Final === The final has been played at the rebuilt [[Páirc Uí Chaoimh]] since it opened in 2017. The rebuilding process meant that the finals of 2015 and 2016 were hosted at [[Páirc Uí Rinn]]. Prior to rebuilding, the final was hosted by the original Páirc Uí Chaoimh since it opened in 1976. The final was played at [[Mardyke (UCC)|the Mardyke]] in 1974 and 1975, while in the 70 years prior to the development of Páirc Uí Chaoimh the final was usually played at the [[Cork Athletic Grounds]]. From the inaugural championship in 1887 up to the turn of the 20th century, the final was held at Cork Park.
==Managers==
[[Manager (Gaelic Games)|Managers]] in the Cork Championship are involved in the day-to-day running of the team, including the training, team selection, and sourcing of players. Their influence varies from club-to-club and is related to the individual club committees. The manager is assisted by a team of two or three selectors and a backroom team consisting of various coaches.

==Trophy==
The winning team is presented with the Seán Óg Murphy Cup. A native of Cork city, [[Seán Óg Murphy]] (1897–1956) played hurling for [[Blackrock GAA|Blackrock]] and Gaelic football for [[Nil Desperandum GAA|Nils]]. He won three [[All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship|All-Ireland]] medals with [[Cork GAA|Cork]] and served as secretary of the Cork County Board from 1929 until his death in 1956. The cup is similar in design to the [[Liam MacCarthy Cup]].

===Teams===
====By decade====
The most successful team of each decade, judged by number of Cork Senior Hurling Championship titles, is as follows:
* 1880s: 2 for [[Blackrock GAA|Blackrock]] (1887–89) * 1890s: 6 for [[Blackrock GAA|Blackrock]] (1891-93-94-95-97-98) * 1900s: 3 for [[St. Finbarr's GAA|St. Finbarr's]] (1904-05-06) * 1910s: 4 for [[Blackrock GAA|Blackrock]] (1910-11-12-13) * 1920s: 5 for [[St. Finbarr's GAA|St. Finbarr's]] (1920-24-25-27-29) * 1930s: 6 for [[Glen Rovers GAA|Glen Rovers]] (1934-35-36-37-38-39) * 1940s: 6 for [[Glen Rovers GAA|Glen Rovers]] (1940-41-44-45-48-49) * 1950s: 5 for [[Glen Rovers GAA|Glen Rovers]] (1950-53-54-57-58) * 1960s: 5 for [[Glen Rovers GAA|Glen Rovers]] (1960-62-64-67-69) * 1970s: 5 for [[Blackrock GAA|Blackrock]] (1971-73-75-78-79) * 1980s: 5 for [[St. Finbarr's GAA|St. Finbarr's]] (1980-81-82-84-88) * 1990s: 2 each for [[Na Piarsaigh GAA|Na Piarsaigh]] (1990–95) and [[Imokilly GAA|Imokilly]] (1997–98) * 2000s: 4 for [[Newtownshandrum GAA|Newtownshandrum]] (2000-03-05-09) * 2010s: 3 for [[Sarsfields GAA (Cork)|Sarsfields]] (2010-12-14)
====Successful defending====
Only 7 teams of the 19 who have won the championship have ever successfully defended the title. These are: * [[Glen Rovers GAA|Glen]] Rovers on 14 attempts out of 26 (1935, 1936, 1937, 1938, 1939, 1940, 1941, 1945, 1949, 1950, 1954, 1959, 1960, 2016) * [[Blackrock GAA|Blackrock]] on 11 attempts out of 31 (1894, 1895, 1898, 1911, 1912, 1913, 1925, 1930, 1931, 1979, 2002) * [[St. Finbarr's GAA|St. Finbarr's]] on 8 attempts out of 24 (1905, 1906, 1923, 1933, 1943, 1947, 1981, 1982) * [[Imokilly GAA|Imokilly]] on 2 attempts out of 3 (1997, 2018) * [[Redmonds GAA|Redmonds]] on 1 attempt out of 4 (1901) * [[Midleton GAA|Midleton]] on 1 attempt out of 6 (1987) * [[Erin's Own GAA (Cork)|Erin's Own]] on 1 attempt out of 2 (2007)
====Gaps====
Top ten longest gaps between successive championship titles: * 93 years: [[Carrigtwohill GAA|Carrigtwohill]] (1918-2011) * 67 years: [[Midleton GAA|Midleton]] (1916-1983) * 51 years: [[Sarsfields GAA (Cork)|Sarsfields]] (1957-2008) * 30 years: [[Avondhu GAA|Avondhu]] (1966-1996) * 26 years: [[Glen Rovers GAA|Glen Rovers]] (1989-2015) * 25 years: [[Blackrock GAA|Blackrock]] (1931-1956) * 22 years: [[Midleton GAA|Midleton]](1991-2013) * 19 years: [[Imokilly GAA|Imokilly]] (1998-2017) * 14 years: [[Redmonds GAA|Redmonds]] (1901-1915) * 14 years: [[Blackrock GAA|Blackrock]] (1985-1999) * 14 years: [[Erin's Own GAA (Cork)|Erin's Own]] (1992-2006)

==Winners and finalists== ===The Double===
Three teams have won the Cork Senior Hurling Championship and the [[Cork Senior Football Championship]] in a single year as part of a hurling-[[Gaelic football]] [[The Double (Gaelic Games)|double]]. [[Glen Rovers GAA|Glen Rovers]] and their sister club, [[St. Nicholas' GAA|St. Nicholas']], became the first teams to win the double in 1938 before claiming two further doubles in 1941 and 1954. [[UCC GAA|University College Cork]] won their only double in 1963. [[St. Finbarr's GAA|St. Finbarr's]] hold the distinction of being the only single entity club team to have won the double. They achieved this in 1980 and 1982.
Divisional sides [[Avondhu GAA|Avondhu]], [[Carbery GAA|Carbery]] and [[Imokilly GAA|Imokilly]] and club team [[Midleton GAA|Midleton]] also hold the distinction of being dual county senior championship-winning teams, however, these were not achieved in a single calendar season.
==See also==
* [[List of Cork Senior Hurling Championship winners]]
==Media coverage==
[[C103]] & [[CRY 104.0FM]] provides extensive radio coverage of the championship, including several full live commentaries from Round 1 to the final. Both will cover the final live.
The Big Red Bench on [[Cork's Red FM]] cover most games with reports and updates on radio and their Twitter Feed
[[TG4]] has carried live and deferred television broadcasts of several finals over the years as part of its ''[[GAA Beo]]'' programme.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Cork Senior Hurling Championship}} {{Cork clubs competitions}}
[[Category:Cork Senior Hurling Championship| ]] [[Category:Hurling competitions in County Cork|1]] [[Category:Senior hurling county championships]] [[Category:1887 establishments in Ireland]] [[Category:Recurring sporting events established in 1887]]

revision.text:
[[File:US Navy 031230-N-9693M-018 Navy quarterback Craig Candeto gains yardage on a rushing attempt during the EV1.Net Houston Bowl at Reliant Stadium in Houston, Texas.jpg|thumb|Navy quarterback Craig Candeto rushing]]
In [[gridiron football]], a '''dual-threat quarterback''', also known as a '''running quarterback''',<ref name=Benoit14>{{cite web|last=Benoit|first=Andy|url=http://mmqb.si.com/2014/06/05/andrew-luck-russell-wilson-colin-kaepernick-robert-griffin-cam-newtown-running-quarterbacks-analysis/|title=NFL’s Best Running Quarterback? The Answer May Surprise You|publisher=''Sports Illustrated''|work=The MMQB|date=June 5, 2014|accessdate=December 8, 2014}}</ref> is a [[quarterback]] who possesses the skills and physique to run with the ball if necessary. With the rise of several blitz heavy defensive schemes and increasingly faster defensive players, the importance of a mobile quarterback has been redefined. While arm power, accuracy, and [[Passing pocket|pocket]] presence – the ability to successfully operate from within the "pocket" formed by his blockers – are still the most important quarterback virtues, the ability to elude or run past defenders creates an additional threat that allows greater flexibility in the team's passing and running game. Overall, the dual-threat quarterback has been referred to as "the most complex position in sports" by [[Bleacher Report]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2274521-br-cfb-250-top-20-dual-threat-quarterbacks|title=B/R CFB 250: Top 20 Dual-Threat Quarterbacks|publisher=''Bleacher Report''|date=December 15, 2014|accessdate=December 15, 2014}}</ref>
Dual-threat quarterbacks have historically been more prolific at the college level. Typically, a quarterback with exceptional quickness is used in an option offense, which allows the quarterback to either hand the ball off, run it himself, or pitch it to the running back following him at a distance of three yards outside and one yard behind. This type of offense forces defenders to commit to either the running back up the middle, the quarterback around the end, or the running back trailing the quarterback. It is then that the quarterback has the "option" to identify which match up is most favorable to the offense as the play unfolds and exploit that defensive weakness. In the college game, many schools employ several plays that are designed for the quarterback to run with the ball.
This is much less common in professional football, except for a [[quarterback sneak]], but there is still an emphasis on being mobile enough to escape a heavy [[Rush (American football)|pass rush]]. Historically, dual threat quarterbacks in the [[National Football League]] (NFL) were uncommon, with [[Micheal Vick|Michael Vick]] being considered a rarity in the early 2000s.{{cn|date=February 2017}} In recent years, quarterbacks with dual-threat capabilities have become more popular. Current NFL starting quarterbacks considered to be dual threats include [[Cam Newton]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wesseling|first1=Chris|title=Is Cam Newton the greatest dual-threat QB in history?|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000630307/article/is-cam-newton-the-greatest-dualthreat-qb-in-history|accessdate=February 11, 2017|work=NFL.com|publisher=National Football League|date=July 6, 2016}}</ref> [[Russell Wilson]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Samuel|first1=Ebenezer|title=Super Bowl XLVIII: Russell Wilson is the man on the run|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/football/seahawks-qb-wilson-man-run-article-1.1598867|accessdate=February 11, 2017|work=New York Daily News|date=February 1, 2014|quote=If Russell Wilson can make good decisions on Sunday night at MetLife Stadium, he may finally change the NFL's perception of the dual-threat quarterback.}}</ref> [[Marcus Mariota]],<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.espn.com/blog/nflnation/post/_/id/253430/pocket-passing-lesson-helps-dual-threat-marcus-mariota-for-long-term|title = Pocket passing lesson helps dual-threat Marcus Mariota for long term|first = Cameron|last = Wolfe|date = October 19, 2017|accessdate = December 18, 2017|publisher=ESPN}}</ref> [[Deshaun Watson]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/ncaaf/2017/01/08/alabama-jalen-hurts-clemson-deshaun-watson-dual-threat-qb/96322194/|title=Deshaun Watson, Jalen Hurts see 'dual-threat QB' in different light|publisher = USA Today|date = January 8, 2017|accessdate = August 24, 2018}}</ref> [[Mitchell Trubisky]],<ref>{{cite news|url = https://www.profootballweekly.com/2018/10/23/schofield-mitch-trubisky-emerging-as-dangerous-dual-threat/au18wnm/|title = Mitch Trubisky emerging as dangerous dual threat|first = Mark|last = Schofield|work = Pro Football Weekly|date = October 23, 2018|accessdate = October 28, 2018}}</ref> [[Lamar Jackson]],<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.baltimoreravens.com/news/lamar-jackson-shows-dual-threat-ability-makes-big-plays-with-arm | title=Lamar Jackson Shows Dual Threat Ability, Makes Big Plays With Arm | publisher=Baltimore Ravens | date=25 November 2018 | accessdate=26 November 2018 | author=Brown, Clifton}}</ref> [[Josh Allen (quarterback)|Josh Allen]],<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.newyorkupstate.com/expo/sports/erry-2018/11/3c3bdb0131924/welcome-back-josh-allen-8-obse.html | title=Welcome back, Josh Allen: 8 observations from rookie's return to Bills (videos) | publisher=NewYorkUpstate.com | accessdate=25 November 2018 | author=Parrino, Matt|quote=The big arm is there and the toughness is there, but he's able to accelerate and run away from linebackers at the second level. He's a true dual-threat quarterback.}}</ref> and, to a lesser extent, [[Aaron Rodgers]],<ref>https://packerswire.usatoday.com/2017/07/13/packers-qb-aaron-rodgers-is-still-hugely-under-appreciated-as-a-runner/</ref> [[Andrew Luck]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mmqb.si.com/2014/06/05/andrew-luck-russell-wilson-colin-kaepernick-robert-griffin-cam-newtown-running-quarterbacks-analysis/|title=NFL's Best Running Quarterback? The Answer May Surprise You|last=Benoit|first=Andy|work=mmqb.si.com|date=June 5, 2014|accessdate=April 9, 2015}}</ref> [[Dak Prescott]],<ref>{{cite news|url = http://www.star-telegram.com/sports/nfl/dallas-cowboys/article189644354.html|title = Dak Prescott isn’t going to change playing style after Carson Wentz’s injury|first = Drew|last = Davidson|work = Fort Worth Star-Telegram|date = December 13, 2017|accessdate = December 18, 2017}}</ref> [[Patrick Mahomes]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.timescall.com/sports/ci_32235038/pick-your-poison-when-defending-patrick-mahomes | title=Pick your poison when defending Patrick Mahomes | work=The Denver Post | date=27 October 2018 | accessdate=26 November 2018 | author=Ryan O'Halloran}}</ref> and [[Carson Wentz]].<ref>[https://www.12up.com/posts/5729532-this-stat-proves-carson-wentz-is-a-true-dual-threat-qb This Stat Proves Carson Wentz is a True Dual-Threat QB]</ref>
==History in the National Football League== ===Early history (1950s–70s)=== [[File:Tarkenton Scrambling.PNG|thumb|Fran Tarkenton scrambling]] In the 1950s, [[Tobin Rote]], was a rare example of a dual-threat quarterback,<ref name=MDSmith14>{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Michael David|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2014/06/21/vick-isnt-the-first-rushing-quarterback-but-he-is-the-best-for-now/|title=Vick isn’t the first rushing quarterback, but he is the best (for now)|publisher=''NBC Sports''|work=Pro Football Talk|date=June 21, 2014|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> as he led the [[Green Bay Packers]] in rushing in 3 seasons, and retired with 3,128 yards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nfl.packers.com/news/releases/2000/06/06-28b.html|title=Packer Hall of Famer Tobin Rote Dead at 72|publisher=''Green Bay Packers''|date=June 28, 2000|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Litsky|first=Frank|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/06/30/sports/tobin-rote-72-a-championship-quarterback-for-the-lions.html|title=Tobin Rote, 72, a Championship Quarterback for the Lions|publisher=''The New York Times''|date=June 30, 2000|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> As of the end of [[2017 NFL season]], Rote still ranks 10th all time in rushing yards for a quarterback.<ref name=Rotestats/>
The next decade, however, saw [[Fran Tarkenton]] impact the game in both passing and running aspects. Tarkenton writes, "When I began my NFL career in 1961, I was a freak. The reason was simple: I played quarterback and I ran. There were no designed runs in our playbook, but I would scramble out of the pocket when a play broke down."<ref name=Tarkenton13>{{cite web|last=Tarkenton|first=Fran|url=http://www.twincities.com/ci_22379070/fran-tarkenton-1961-i-was-freak-today-running|title=Fran Tarkenton: 'In 1961, I was a freak.' Today, running quarterbacks embraced|publisher=''Twin Cities''|date=January 15, 2013|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> Tarkenton adds by describing the reaction to his scrambling at the time, "It was not a skill set that was embraced. Plenty of people mocked it, and the rest wrote it off."<ref name=Tarkenton13/> At the time of his retirement, Tarkenton was the all-time leader in rushing yards by a quarterback, with 3,674.<ref name=Jones13>{{cite web|last=Jones|first=Riley|url=http://sneakerreport.com/news/perf-sneaker-history-randall-cunningham-qb-rushing-record-nike/|title=Today in Performance Sneaker History: Randall Cunningham Sets QB Rushing Record in Nike Cleats|publisher=''Sneaker Report''|date=October 18, 2013|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref>
In 1972, [[Chicago Bears]] quarterback [[Bobby Douglass]] set the single-season rushing yards record for a quarterback, as he logged 968 yards.<ref name=Yellon10>{{cite web|last=Yellon|first=Al|url=http://chicago.sbnation.com/2010/8/31/1657421/bears-quarterback-controversy-jay-cutler-bobby-douglass|title=Bobby Douglass: A Bears Quarterback Who Was One Of A Kind|publisher=''SB Nation''|work=Chicago|date=August 31, 2010|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> Douglass, however, was not considered a good passer, as his receivers complained his arm strength was, "too strong," as he often overthrew the ball.<ref name=Yellon10/> The Bears attempted to create wild schemes, before discovering his rushing ability, leading to his record-breaking 1972 season.<ref name=Yellon10/>
Another rare dual-threat quarterback that emerged in the 1970s was [[Steve Grogan]]. While playing college football for [[Kansas State Wildcats football|Kansas State]], Grogan had rushed for a 100-yard game, and had over 500 yards in two seasons as a starter. Drafted by the [[New England Patriots]] in 1975, Grogan scored 12 rushing touchdowns in the [[1976 New England Patriots season|1976 season]], a record for quarterbacks which stood for 35 years. During the [[1978 New England Patriots season|1978 season]], Grogan ran for 539 yards, on a team which set the NFL record for total rushing yards (3,165), which still stands as of 2018. Limited by injuries during the middle part of his career, Grogan would transition to a more traditional pocket-passer by the middle 1980s.
===Rise (1980s−2000s)=== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | image1 = Randall Cunningham Pro Bowl.JPG | width1 = {{#expr: (250 * 150 / 344) round 0}} | alt1 = | image2 = SteveYoungAnalyst.PNG | width2 = {{#expr: (500 * 520 / 1430) round 0}} | alt2 = | footer = Randall Cunningham (left) and Steve Young (right) were prominent dual-threat QBs during the 1980s and 90s | footer_align = left }}
During the 1980s and 90s, dual-threat quarterbacks were more frequently seen than in previous decades. [[Randall Cunningham]] and [[Steve Young]] were the faces of rushing quarterbacks during this era. Cunningham was able to exceed Young in statistical regards. On October 18, 1992, Cunningham surpassed Tarkenton's record for career rushing yards by a quarterback.<ref name=Jones13/> Following the 2001 NFL season, Cunningham retired with a then-record 4,928 rushing yards. Despite Cunningham having more rushing yards, Young held the record for most career rushing touchdowns by a quarterback (43) until being surpassed by [[Cam Newton]] in 2016.<ref name=LeBeau11>{{cite web|last=LeBeau|first=James|url=http://www.craveonline.com/sports/articles/176896-top-5-rushing-quarterbacks-of-all-time|title=Top 5 Rushing Quarterbacks Of All Time|publisher=''CraveOnline''|date=October 26, 2011|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://bleacherreport.com/articles/2662596-cam-newton-passes-steve-young-for-most-rushing-tds-by-a-qb-in-nfl-history|title=Cam Newton Passes Steve Young for Most Rushing TDs by a QB in NFL History|publisher=''Bleacher Report''|date=September 8, 2016}}</ref>
There is debate as to whether Young or Cunningham was the better rushing quarterback. ''[[CraveOnline]]'' writes that, although, "there may be two others [Vick and Cunningham] that hold an edge to Steve Young in amount of yards rushed, career wise, by a QB but make no mistake about it, if you are a QB that can run, then Young is who you want to emulate," adding that, Young, "had the rare gift of explosive speed combined with deadly accuracy."<ref name=LeBeau11/> As for Cunningham, [[Jeff Darlington]], an NFL Media reporter, writes, "True, Steve Young had legs that merited the respect of defenders. But Cunningham ... Cunningham was different. And today's quarterbacks know it."<ref name=Darlington13>{{cite web|last=Darlington|first=Jeff|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000154103/printable/randall-cunningham-at-50-reflections-on-career-new-qbs-more|title=Randall Cunningham at 50: Reflections on career, new QBs, more|publisher=''NFL.com''|date=March 26, 2013|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> Darlington adds to his point by referring to an anecdote from [[Robert Griffin III]], a 2010s rushing quarterback, in which Griffin III would watch Cunningham's highlights with his father.<ref name=Darlington13/> Griffin III elaborates, "We'd watch how well he moved in the pocket to avoid defenders and make plays -- not just with his legs, but with his arm. He was one of the first true game-changers the league saw."<ref name=Darlington13/>
Aside from Cunningham and Young, [[Steve McNair]] and [[Kordell Stewart]] were also considered dynamic running quarterbacks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsports.com/nfl/story/former-pittsburgh-steelers-quarterback-kordell-stewart-retires-at-39-053012|title=Ex-Steelers QB Kordell Stewart retires|publisher=''Fox Sports''|date=June 2, 2014|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref><ref name=LookbackMcNair>{{cite web|url=http://www.titansonline.com/news/article-1/A-Look-Back-at-the-Career-of-Steve-McNair/7bafa73a-0a67-4b0b-847d-c74e278737fb|title=A Look Back at the Career of Steve McNair|publisher=''Tennessee Titans''|date=July 4, 2009|accessdate=December 10, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150214075337/http://www.titansonline.com/news/article-1/a-look-back-at-the-career-of-steve-mcnair/7bafa73a-0a67-4b0b-847d-c74e278737fb|archive-date=2015-02-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
[[File:Michael Vick running, November 2006.jpg|thumb|Michael Vick running during his record 2006 season]] As Young, Cunningham, and [[John Elway]], another dual-threat QB from the 1980s and 90s, all retired from 1998 to 2001, a new generation of mobile quarterbacks was ushered in. [[Donovan McNabb]] was drafted by the Eagles in 1999, beginning a successful quarterbacking career, in which his running ability was frequently identified.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kolp|first=Curt|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/137504-donovan-mcnabb-the-greatest-philadelphia-eagle-quarterback-of-all-time|title=Donovan McNabb: The Greatest Philadelphia Eagle Quarterback of All Time?|publisher=''Bleacher Report''|date=March 11, 2009|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Silver|first=Michael|url=https://www.si.com/vault/2003/01/20/336208/back-in-stride-buoyed-by-donovan-mcnabbs-speedy-recovery-the-eagles-advanced-to-their-second-straight-nfc-championship-game|title=Back in Stride Buoyed by Donovan McNabb's speedy recovery, the Eagles advanced to their second straight NFC Championship Game|publisher=''Sports Illustrated''|work=The Vault|date=January 20, 2003|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> On his mobility, McNabb once joked, "I think you run a lot better when you don't want to be hit."<ref name=Longman03>{{cite web|last=Longman|first=Jere|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/01/08/sports/pro-football-mcnabb-starts-anew.html|title=PRO FOOTBALL; McNabb Starts Anew|publisher=''The New York Times''|date=January 8, 2003|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> After sustaining an injury in the 2003 season, there was speculation as to if McNabb would be able to retain his mobility, as [[Ray Buchanan]] stated, "We'd probably rather see McNabb, because he's not as mobile right now," which McNabb responded with, "According to everyone else I'm not mobile. I'll just let people continue to think that, and when the time comes, I'll make sure I showcase that a little bit."<ref name=Longman03/>
McNabb was also connected to [[Michael Vick]], one of the most prolific running quarterbacks in the history of the NFL.<ref>{{cite web|last=Spiegelman|first=Sam|url=http://highschoolsports.nola.com/news/article/8063056283384459619/new-york-jets-qb-michael-vick-to-visit-independence-stadium-in-shreveport-friday-site-says/|title=New York Jets QB Michael Vick to visit Independence Stadium in Shreveport Friday, site says|publisher=''The Times-Picayune|work=High School Sports|date=July 10, 2014|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> While attending [[Syracuse University]], McNabb attempted to assist in the recruitment of [[Michael Vick]], and in addition to that, McNabb also mentored Vick about the speed of the professional level.<ref name=Longman03/> Vick also served as McNabb's backup in [[Philadelphia]] in 2009, later succeeding McNabb as the starter for the franchise.<ref name=Rhoden10>{{cite web|last=Rhoden|first=William C.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/22/sports/football/22rhoden.html?_r=0|title=An Unsung Role in Vick’s Success|publisher=''The New York Times''|date=November 22, 2010|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> Michael Vick was drafted first overall by [[Atlanta Falcons]] in 2001.<ref name=Vrentas14>{{cite web|last=Vrentas|first=Jenny|url=http://mmqb.si.com/2014/08/22/michael-vick-new-york-jets/|title=The Franchise Backup|publisher=''Sports Illustrated''|work=The MMQB|date=August 22, 2014|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> Vick would go on to be a successful runner for the Falcons from 2001 to 2006.<ref name=SIWire14>{{cite web|author=SI Wire|url=https://www.si.com/sports/nfl/2014/06/23/jets-michael-vick-revolutionized-game|title=Jets quarterback Michael Vick: 'I revolutionized the game'|publisher=''Sports Illustrated''|date=June 23, 2014|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> 14 games into his 2006 season, Vick broke Douglass' single-season rushing yards record by a quarterback.<ref>{{cite web|last=Newberry|first=Paul|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/12/16/AR2006121601262.html|title=Vick Breaks 34-Year-Old Rushing Record|publisher=''Washington Post''|date=December 17, 2006|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> A week later, Vick surpassed the 1,000 rushing yards milestone, becoming the first quarterback to reach the mark in a single season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2707909|title=Vick first NFL QB to rush for 1,000 yards in season|publisher=''ESPN''|date=December 24, 2006|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> He finished the season with a record 1,039 yards.<ref name=Vickstats>{{cite web|url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/V/VickMi00.htm|title=Michael Vick|publisher=''Sports-Reference''|work=Pro Football Reference|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> Vick's mobility influenced future mobile quarterbacks; Jenny Vrentas of ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' writes, "Young players go out of their way to tell Vick that they were always him when they played ''[[Madden NFL|Madden]]'' growing up, and wore his [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] cleats."<ref name=Vrentas14/>
===Peak (2010s)=== After his return to the NFL, and a season as McNabb's backup, Vick earned his second starting opportunity. His [[2010 NFL season|2010]] rushing statistics (league-leading 676 yards among quarterbacks and 9 touchdowns<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/stats/categorystats?tabSeq=0&statisticCategory=RUSHING&conference=null&season=2010&seasonType=REG&d-447263-s=RUSHING_YARDS&d-447263-o=2&d-447263-n=1|title=NFL Stats: by Player Category (Rushing, 2010)|publisher=''NFL.com''|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref>) were the foundation for the landscape of mobile quarterbacks during the early 2010s. [[2011 NFL season|The following season]], on October 9, Vick surpassed Cunningham's career rushing yardage total, to claim the career-record for quarterbacks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d822f640e/article/vick-breaks-cunninghams-nfl-record-for-qb-rushing-yards|title=Vick breaks Cunningham's NFL record for QB rushing yards|publisher=''NFL.com''|date=October 9, 2011|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> That season also saw [[Cam Newton]] drafted first overall by the [[Carolina Panthers]]. Newton went on to lead quarterbacks in rushing yards with 706, and earned 14 rushing touchdowns, breaking [[Steve Grogan]]'s 1976 single-season record by a quarterback.<ref name=Rush2011>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/stats/categorystats?seasonType=REG&d-447263-n=1&d-447263-o=2&d-447263-p=1&d-447263-s=RUSHING_YARDS&tabSeq=0&season=2011&Submit=Go&experience=&archive=true&statisticCategory=RUSHING&conference=null&qualified=false|title=NFL Stats: by Player Category (Rushing, 2011)|publisher=''NFL.com''|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/nfl/story/2011-12-04/cam-newton-scores-11th-rushing-td-is-within-one-of-record|title=Cam Newton scores three rushing TDs, breaking NFL record|publisher=''Sporting News''|date=December 4, 2011|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> In addition to Newton, notable dual-threat quarterbacks in the early 2010s included [[Aaron Rodgers]], [[Robert Griffin III]], [[Tim Tebow]], [[Colin Kaepernick]], [[Russell Wilson]], and [[Andrew Luck]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Berman|first=Zach|url=http://articles.philly.com/2013-09-06/sports/41804732_1_michael-vick-robert-griffin-read-option|title=Dual-threat QBs Vick and RG3 set to square off|publisher=''Philly''|date=September 6, 2013|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Matoren|first=Steve|url=https://medium.com/@imaliveoutthere/why-no-one-in-the-nfl-wants-tim-tebow-26d93b674ab5|title=Why No One in the NFL Wants Tim Tebow|publisher=''Medium''|date=September 3, 2014|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> On his overall impact and legacy in regards to dual-threat quarterbacks, Vick stated, "I was the guy who started it all," adding, "I revolutionized the game. I changed the way it was played in the NFL."<ref name=SIWire14/><ref>{{cite web|last=Cimini|first=Rick|url=http://espn.go.com/new-york/nfl/story/_/id/11113974/michael-vick-says-pioneered-role-mobile-quarterback|title=Michael Vick: 'I revolutionized' game|publisher=''ESPN''|date=June 20, 2014|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref>
[[File:Aaron rodgers 2014.jpg|thumb|[[Aaron Rodgers]] widely regarded as one of the most talented QBs ever, often uses his mobility to avoid pressure and extend plays.<ref>https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/ftw/2016/12/14/stephen-a-smith-called-aaron-rodgers-the-most-talented-qb-ever-and-hes-absolutely-correct/95427218/</ref><ref>https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/this-odd-stat-might-be-proof-that-aaron-rodgers-could-claim-to-be-best-qb-ever/</ref><ref>http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2726739-the-top-10-quarterbacks-of-all-time</ref>]] In the 2014 season, Kaepernick, Griffin III, and Newton were all cited as declining or regressing players.<ref name=PKing14>{{cite web|last=King|first=Peter|url=http://mmqb.si.com/2014/12/03/quarterback-market-draft-2015/|title=The QB Market Crash|publisher=''Sports Illustrated''|work=The MMQB|date=December 3, 2014|accessdate=December 9, 2014}}</ref> Kaepernick was labeled, "symbolic of running QB struggles," by NFL.com writer, Chris Wesseling.<ref name=Wesseling12814>{{cite web|last=Wesseling|first=Chris|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000438587/article/colin-kaepernick-symbolic-of-running-qb-struggles|title=Colin Kaepernick symbolic of running QB struggles|publisher=''NFL.com''|date=December 8, 2014|accessdate=December 9, 2014}}</ref> This status came after Kaepernick and the [[San Francisco 49ers|49ers]] were defeated by [[Derek Carr (American football)|Derek Carr]] and the [[Oakland Raiders]]. Carr is not considered a dual-threat quarterback, though his, "mindset, athleticism, pocket presence, quick release and strong arm" have all been praised by executives, coaches and analysts.<ref name=Wesseling12814/> [[Steve Young]], who ranks third all-time in rushing yards for a quarterback, was cited as believing scrambling away from pressure limits and stunts the development of a quarterback's [[passing pocket|pocket presence]].<ref name=Wesseling12814/><ref name=BranchNov14>{{cite web|last=Branch|first=Eric|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/49ers/2014/11/21/steve-young-and-the-art-of-molding-a-mobile-quarterback/|title=Steve Young and the art of molding a mobile quarterback|publisher=''San Francisco Gate''|date=November 21, 2014|accessdate=December 9, 2014}}</ref> During the season, [[Bill Polian]], a former [[Indianapolis Colts]] president, stated, "What we're seeing this year is the incredible erosion of the running quarterback."<ref name=PKing14/> Obstacles such as high expectations and an increased potential for injury hindered the perception that mobile quarterbacks would become the dominant breed of the position.<ref name=Boyer14>{{cite web|last=Boyer|first=Zac|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/nov/20/rg3-colin-kaepernick-cam-newton-russell-wilson-adj/?page=all|title=Pocket Change: NFL’s young, mobile QBs caught in adjustment process|publisher=''Washington Times''|date=November 20, 2014|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref>
While Kaepernick, Newton, and Griffin III struggled during the season, mobility in other quarterbacks was praised. Success in the passing game, while having mobility to extend the play, was regarded more highly than pure running athleticism in 2014. Aaron Rodgers' mobility, for example, was considered by one NFL.com writer to be critical to the Packers' offense.<ref>{{cite web|last=Patra|first=Kevin|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000422716/article/aaron-rodgers-hamstring-looked-good-in-workout|title=Aaron Rodgers (hamstring) 'looked good' in workout|publisher=''NFL.com''|work=Around the NFL|date=November 4, 2014|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> [[New England Patriots]] head coach [[Bill Belichick]] praised Rodgers' mobility, stating, "he has a great ability to extend plays, either sliding in the pocket or at times scrambling outside the pocket."<ref>{{cite web|last=Young|first=Shalise Manza|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/sports/2014/11/26/bill-belichick-heaps-praise-packers-aaron-rodgers/j71RcHskxyyjXXMqVkETaO/story.html|title=Bill Belichick heaps praise on Packers QB Aaron Rodgers|publisher=''Boston Globe''|date=November 26, 2014|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> Luck's mobility was also acclaimed by another NFL head coach, [[Chip Kelly]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Mosher|first=Geoff|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/nbc-yahoo-sports/chip-kelly-on-andrew-luck---he-s-in-that-manning--brady-category-181513044-nfl.html|title=Chip Kelly on Andrew Luck: 'He's in that Manning, Brady category'|publisher=''Yahoo! Sports''|date=September 15, 2014|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> Despite early-season reports of a decline in the performance of dual-threat quarterbacks, Russell Wilson rushed for a career-high 849 yards and 6 touchdowns in 2014,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/W/WilsRu00.htm|title=Russell Wilson|publisher=''Sports-Reference''|work=Pro Football Reference|accessdate=January 26, 2016}}</ref> leading the Seattle Seahawks to a second consecutive [[Super Bowl XLIX|Super Bowl appearance]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Tomasson|first=Chris|url=http://www.twincities.com/2015/01/30/super-bowl-seahawks-aiming-for-rare-repeat-championship/|title=Super Bowl: Seahawks aiming for rare repeat championship|publisher=''St. Paul Pioneer Press''|date=January 30, 2015|accessdate=January 26, 2016}}</ref>
New dual-threat quarterbacks emerged as starters during [[2015 NFL season|2015]] such as [[Marcus Mariota]] and [[Tyrod Taylor]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pelissero|first1=Tom|title=Rex Ryan: NFL will soon learn Tyrod Taylor is a 'special talent'|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/bills/2016/08/01/tyrod-taylor-dual-threat-special-talent-high-expectations-buffalo-bills/87902686/|accessdate=February 11, 2017|work=USA Today|date=August 1, 2016}}</ref> Also in 2015, Cam Newton had a resurgent season, scoring 10 rushing touchdowns en route to a [[Super Bowl 50|Super Bowl berth]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Schein|first=Adam|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000628116/article/cam-newton-is-quite-simply-the-best-player-in-the-nfl-today|title=Cam Newton is, quite simply, the best player in the NFL today|publisher=''NFL''|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016}}</ref> However, as Newton was also successful in his passing game, one ''[[The Wall Street Journal|Wall Street Journal]]'' reporter wrote "defenses say it is Newton's ability to do anything on any given play that really keeps them up at night", adding "[Newton] is a pass-first quarterback capable of picking up a first down with his legs at any moment."<ref name=Clark2016>{{cite web|last=Clark|first=Kevin|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/why-cam-newton-cant-be-stopped-1453850723|title=Why Cam Newton Can't Be Stopped|publisher=''The Wall Street Journal''|date=January 26, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016}}</ref>

2016}}</ref> |- |Cam Newton |[[2015 NFL season|2015]] |Carolina Panthers |10<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/N/NewtCa00/touchdowns/2015/|title=Cam Newton 2015 ==History in the Canadian Football League== The width of the CFL's field at 65 yards and the length at 110 yards has allowed quarterbacks to find openings to run the ball, implementing improvisation by a quarterback as a beneficial trait in [[Canadian football]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.13thman.com/cflvsnfl.html |title=CFL vs NFL |publisher=13thman.com |accessdate=January 5, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150105203148/http://www.13thman.com/cflvsnfl.html |archivedate=January 5, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2190906-bo-levi-mitchell-shows-that-cfl-quarterbacks-are-not-wimps |title=Bo Levi Mitchell Shows That CFL Quarterbacks Are Not Wimps |publisher=bleacherreport.com |date=September 8, 2014 |accessdate=January 5, 2015 |author=Flannery,Jim |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150105204604/http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2190906-bo-levi-mitchell-shows-that-cfl-quarterbacks-are-not-wimps |archivedate=January 5, 2015 }}</ref> [[Quarterback sneak]]s or other runs in short yardage situations tend to be successful as a result of the distance between the [[offensive line|offensive]] and [[defensive line]]s being one yard. [[Drew Tate]], a quarterback for the [[Calgary Stampeders]]', led the CFL in rushing touchdowns during the [[2014 CFL season|2014 season]] with ten scores as the backup to [[Bo Levi Mitchell]].<ref name="cfl">{{cite web|url=https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/blogs/cfl-55-yard-line/backup-quarterback-drew-tate-plays-major-role-in-limited-time-in-stampeders--grey-cup-win-045955279.html |title=Backup quarterback Drew Tate plays major role in limited time in Stampeders' Grey Cup win |publisher=ca.sports.yahoo.com |date=November 30, 2014 |accessdate=January 5, 2015 |author=Denomme, Ian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150105210801/https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/blogs/cfl-55-yard-line/backup-quarterback-drew-tate-plays-major-role-in-limited-time-in-stampeders--grey-cup-win-045955279.html |archivedate=January 5, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cfl.ca/statistics/league/stat/Rushing/year/2014/type/reg |title=Rushing - 2014 |publisher=cfl.ca |accessdate=January 5, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150105210152/http://cfl.ca/statistics/league/stat/Rushing/year/2014/type/reg |archivedate=January 5, 2015 }}</ref> He was primarily used in short yardage situations due to his speed and running ability. Tate scored two one-yard rushing touchdowns in the Stampeders' 20-16 victory over the [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] in the [[102nd Grey Cup]].<ref name="cfl"/>
===All-time CFL leaders=== ====Rushing yards==== [[File:Damon Allen running.jpg|thumb|Damon Allen as an Argonaut]] {| class="wikitable sortable" |- style="white-space: nowrap;" !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Rank !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Player !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|[[List of CFL seasons|Seasons]] by [[Canadian Football League#Teams|team]] !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Total rushing yards |- |1 |[[Damon Allen]] |[[Edmonton Eskimos]] ([[1985 CFL season|1985]]–[[1988 CFL season|1988]])<br/>[[Ottawa Rough Riders]] ([[1989 CFL season|1989]]–[[1991 CFL season|1991]])<br/>[[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] ([[1992 CFL season|1992]])<br/>[[Edmonton Eskimos]] ([[1993 CFL season|1993]]–[[1994 CFL season|1994]])<br/>[[Memphis Mad Dogs]] ([[1995 CFL season|1995]])<br/>[[BC Lions]] ([[1996 CFL season|1996]]–[[2002 CFL season|2002]])<br/>[[Toronto Argonauts]] ([[2003 CFL season|2003]]–[[2007 CFL season|2007]]) |style="text-align:right;"|11,920<ref name="cfl.ca">{{cite web|url=https://www.cfl.ca/page/stats_indrec_rushing |title=Regular Season All-Time Records |publisher=cfl.ca |accessdate=January 4, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150104163054/http://www.cfl.ca/page/stats_indrec_rushing |archivedate=January 4, 2015 }}</ref> |- |2 |[[Tracy Ham]] |[[Edmonton Eskimos]] ([[1987 CFL season|1987]]–[[1992 CFL season|1992]])<br/>[[Toronto Argonauts]] ([[1993 CFL season|1993]])<br/>[[Baltimore Stallions]] ([[1994 CFL season|1994]]–[[1995 CFL season|1995]])<br/>[[Montreal Alouettes]] ([[1996 CFL season|1996]]–[[1999 CFL season|1999]]) |style="text-align:right;"|8,043<ref name="cfl.ca"/> |- |3 |[[Jackie Parker]] |[[Edmonton Eskimos]] ([[1954 in Canadian football|1954]]–[[1962 CFL season|1962]])<br/>[[Toronto Argonauts]] ([[1963 CFL season|1963]]–[[1965 CFL season|1965]])<br/>[[BC Lions]] ([[1966 CFL season|1966]]–[[1968 CFL season|1968]]) |style="text-align:right;"|5,210<ref name="cfl.ca"/> |}

revision.text:
'''Dubai World Cup Night''' is a series of eight [[thoroughbred horse race]]s and one Purebred Arabian race held annually at [[Meydan Racecourse]] in [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]]. From 1996 through to 2009, the event was held at the [[Nad Al Sheba Racecourse]].
Run under the auspices of the Emirates Racing Authority, the event currently offers purses totalling US$27.25 million and is the single richest day of [[Thoroughbred]] racing in the world. The Dubai World Cup Night includes the following races:
* [[Dubai Kahayla Classic]] GI (for purebred [[Arabian horse|Arabians]]) * [[Al Quoz Sprint]] GI * [[Godolphin Mile]] GII * [[Dubai Gold Cup]] GII * [[UAE Derby]] GII * [[Dubai Golden Shaheen]] GI (part of the [[Global Sprint Challenge]] since 2012) * [[Dubai Turf]] GI (was part of the [[Asian Mile Challenge]]) * [[Dubai Sheema Classic]] GI * [[Dubai World Cup]] GI (The World's Richest Horse Race at USD $10,000,000)
==References== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100208133159/http://www.meydan.ae/racecourse/ Meydan Racecourse] * [http://wayback.vefsafn.is/wayback/20070505134746/http://www.drf.com/admin/NewsLogin.jsp ESPN report on the 2008 Dubai World Cup Night]
{{UnitedArabEmirates-sport-stub}} {{horseracing-stub}}

A Goal Would Be Terrific|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2013-12-05}}{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-09-19/an-beach-soccer-kick-off/4967946 |title=Tahiti emerging as strong contenders for Beach Soccer World Cup - Australia Network News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=2013-09-19 |accessdate=2013-12-05}} With 146 association football clubs and over 11,200 registered players, football is far and away the most popular sport among the inhabitants on the island of Tahiti. https://www.oceaniafootball.com/tahiti/ ==League system== {| class="wikitable" cellpadding="0" style="text-align:center; width:100%;" |- style="background:#efefef;" | style="width:4%; text-align:center;"| '''Level''' | colspan="12" style="width:96%; text-align:center;"| '''League(s)/Division(s)''' |- | style="text-align:center; width:4%; background:#efefef;"| 1 | colspan="12" style="width:96%; text-align:center;"| '''[[Tahiti Ligue 1|Ligue 1 Vini]]'''

revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox building | name = Hong Kong Coliseum | native_name = | former_names = | alternate_names = | image = Hong Kong Coliseum 2008.jpg | alt = | caption = Hong Kong Coliseum | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = | altitude = | building_type = | architectural_style = [[Minimalism]] | structural_system = [[reinforced concrete]] | cost = HK$ 140 000 000
HK$ 160 000 000 (2008 renovation) | client = [[Urban Council, Hong Kong|Urban Council]] | owner = | current_tenants = | landlord = | location = | address = | location_town = [[Hung Hom Bay]], [[Kowloon]] | location_country = {{HKG}} | coordinates = | start_date = March 1973 | completion_date = August 1981 | inauguration_date = | renovation_date = | demolition_date = | destruction_date = | capacity = 12,500 | height = | diameter = | floor_count = | floor_area = | main_contractor = | architect = | architecture_firm = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | awards = | url = | references = }} {{Chinese |pic=Hong Kong Coliseum Interior 2008.jpg |picsize=300px |piccap=Inside the Hong Kong Coliseum, during the [[FIVB World Grand Prix]] |showflag=y |t=香港體育館 |y=Hēunggóng Táiyuhkgún |ci={{IPA-yue|hœ̂ːŋkɔ̌ːŋ.tǎːijùːkkʊ̌n|}} |j=Hoeng1gong2 Tai2juk6gun2 |altname=Hung Hom Coliseum |t2=紅磡體育館 |y2=Hùhngham Táiyuhkgún |j2=Hung4ham3 Tai2juk6gun2 |t3=紅館 |y3=Hùhnggún |j3=Hung4gun2 }} '''Hong Kong Coliseum''' ({{zh|t=香港體育館}}), commonly known as the '''Hung Hom Coliseum''' (紅磡體育館, 紅館) is a multi-purpose [[indoor arena]], in [[Hung Hom Bay]], [[Kowloon]], [[Hong Kong]]. It was built by the [[Urban Council]] and inaugurated on 27 April 1983. The coliseum has 12,500 seats, which is the second largest among indoor facilities in Hong Kong, only behind the 2005-opened [[AsiaWorld–Arena]]. It is now managed by the [[Leisure and Cultural Service Department]] of the [[Hong Kong Government]]. ==Facilities== The Hong Kong Coliseum consists of a big arena and a number of conference rooms. ===Arena=== [[Image:KCR Hung Hom station exterior (1).jpg|thumb|Hong Kong Coliseum, the inverted [[pyramid]]-like construction, right behind the [[Hung Hom (MTR)|MTR Hung Hom station]].]] The arena is rectangular with sides 41m each, with a [[concrete]] cement flooring. During performances, the floor may be covered with different overmounted floorings, such as demountable wooden flooring or various rubberized roll-outs, to facilitate the set-up of sporting equipment and the playing of different sporting activities such as [[futsal]], [[badminton]], [[basketball]], [[volleyball]] and [[ice-skating]]. Moreover, the floor can hold strong pressures up to 1,800 kg/m2, which cannot even be done by industrial buildings. This facilitates the set up of stages, platforms and sound equipments during [[concerts]] and other concert-like performances that requires an elevated stage and good PA systems. Different technical equipments and a 4-side colour television projection system are also present to project the performer's image onto a screen, so that audience sitting around the rear side of the stadium can also see clearly. ===Conference Rooms=== The Hong Kong Coliseum offers both open and sheltered areas for holding conventions and conferences. The demountable open stage provides the arena with an excellent forum for public assemblies as well as staging live television broadcasts of opening ceremonies. ===Reception Room=== The reception room acts as an assistant facility for hirers of the arena and the conference rooms to accommodate visiting VIPs. The room can hold 60 persons. ==Purposes== Even though its formal name in Chinese roughly translates to "Sports Arena", the [[Sports venue|venue]] often serves as a concert venue for popular singers. In addition, some [[university|universities]] rent it every year for [[congregation (university)|congregation]]. Some performances like [[ice-skating]] also choose Hong Kong Coliseum as their stages. It is also used every year from 1991 to hold the Miss Hong Kong Pageant, except for 2008. It also hosts a part of the FIVB Volleyball Women's Nations League (Before:[[FIVB Volleyball World Grand Prix|FIVB World Grand Prix]]) for volleyball every year. On 3 June 2001, Irish vocal pop band [[Westlife]] held a concert for their [[Where Dreams Come True Tour]] supporting their album [[Coast to Coast (Westlife album)|Coast to Coast]]. ==Venue for 2009 East Asian Games== The Hong Kong Coliseum was one of the venues for the 5th [[East Asian Games]] that was hosted in [[Hong Kong]] in 2009. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Hong Kong Coliseum}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050707025002/http://www.lcsd.gov.hk/CE/Entertainment/Stadia/HKC/index.html Official website of Hong Kong Coliseum] {{coord|22|18|5.33|N|114|10|55.23|E|type:landmark|display=title}} {{s-start}} {{s-sta|et}} {{succession box | title = [[FIFA Futsal World Championship]]
Final Venue| before = [[Sportpaleis Ahoy]]
[[Rotterdam]] | after = [[Palau Sant Jordi]]
[[Barcelona]] | years='''[[1992 FIFA Futsal World Championship|1992]]''' }} {{s-end}} {{Sports venues in Hong Kong}} {{Hong Kong Indoor Sport Centres}} [[Category:Landmarks in Hong Kong]] [[Category:Hung Hom]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Hong Kong]] [[Category:Music venues in Hong Kong]] [[Category:A Symphony of Lights]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in China]] [[Category:Badminton venues]] [[Category:Inverted pyramids]] [[Category:Pyramids in China]] [[Category:Taekwondo venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1981]]

[[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]][[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]][[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]][[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]] | | fullname = | location = Prospekt Khusaina Yamasheva, 115 А, [[Kazan]], [[Russia]] | coordinates = {{coord|55|49|16|N|49|09|39|E|region:RU_type:landmark|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = May 2010 | built = | opened = July 2013 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = [[GrassMaster]] | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]] 450 million | architect = [[Populous (company)|Populous]], V. Motorin | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[FC Rubin Kazan]] (2013–present)
[[Russia national football team]] (selected matches) | seating_capacity = 45,093 ([[Russian Premier League]]){{cite web |url=https://eng.premierliga.ru/stadiums/stadiums_1745.html |title=Kazan Arena}}
42,873 (2018 FIFA World Cup){{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/destination/stadiums/stadium=5028773/index.html |title=Kazan Arena |work=FIFA |access-date=15 June 2018}} | dimensions = 105 x 68 m }} '''Kazan Arena''' ({{lang-rus|«Казань Арена»|}}; {{lang-tt|Казан Арена}}) is a [[stadium]] in [[Kazan]], Russia. It was completed in July 2013, and hosts [[association football|football]] matches, especially [[Rubin Kazan]]'s home games in the [[Russian Premier League]]. The stadium has the largest outside screen in the world. Its capacity is around 45,379.{{cite web|url=http://kazanarena.com/stadium/about/|title=Футбольный стадион «Казань Арена» - Казань Арена|website=kazanarena.com}} ==Overview== [[File:RubinKazanNewStadium.png|thumb|left|The stadium's LED facade is the largest one installed on a football stadium in the world.https://invidis.de/2013/07/kazan-arena-groste-led-fassade-an-einem-fusballstadium/ {{de icon}}]] The architectural concept has been designed by [[Populous (company)|Populous]]; according to lead designer Damon Lavelle, the stadium is a unique response to the local culture and place. The general design stage: "TatInvestGrazhdanProekt", "Intex", "TsNIIpromzdany". It replaced [[Central Stadium (Kazan)|Central Stadium]] as Kazan's main football stadium. The stadium hosted the [[2013 Summer Universiade]] opening and closing ceremonies, and [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup]]. Kazan Arena also hosted the [[2015 World Aquatics Championships]]. The [[2015 World Aquatics Championships|16th FINA World Championships]] were held in Kazan, with some events held at the Arena. It saw twelve swimming records.{{cite web|url=https://theworldgame.sbs.com.au/host-city-kazan|title=Host City - Kazan|publisher=[[Special Broadcasting Service]]|date=1 April 2018}} In the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]], the stadium hosted six matches, including the ones where three past champions (Germany, Argentina, and Brazil) were eliminated from the tournament.
