{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = WIRSOL Rhein-Neckar-Arena | nickname = | image = Rhein-Neckar-Arena Sinsheim.JPG | location = [[Sinsheim]], [[Baden-Württemberg]], [[Germany]] | coordinates = {{coord|49|14|17.1|N|8|53|15.4|E|region:DE-BW_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 2007 | opened = 24 January 2009 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = [[Grass]] | Constructor = | construction_cost = [[Euro|€]]100 million | architect = Eheim Moebel[http://www.eheim-moebel.de/english/arena/rhein-neckar-arena/index.html Rhein-Neckar-Arena] architect: Eheim Moebel
Sattler Europe[http://www.sattler-europe.com/sattler-web/static/media/pdf/Referenz_TA_Rhein-Neckar-Arena_englisch.pdf Rhein-Neckar-Arena] roof: Rhein-Neckar-Arena | former_names = | nicknames = | tenants = [[TSG 1899 Hoffenheim]] (2009–present)
[[Germany national football team]] (selected matches) | seating_capacity = 30,150 (league matches)
25,641 (international matches) | dimensions = }} '''Rhein-Neckar-Arena''' ({{IPA-de|ˌʁaɪnˈnɛkaɐ̯ʔaˌʁeːnaː|-|}}; also known as '''[[Wirsol]] Rhein-Neckar-Arena''' {{IPA-de|ˈvɪʁzɔl-||}} for sponsoring purposes{{cite web|last=Gruener|first=Martin|title=Auch wenn's zwickt: Obasi zaubert und bezaubert|url=http://www.kicker.de/news/fussball/bundesliga/startseite/555508/artikel_auch-wenns-zwickt_obasi-zaubert-und-bezaubert.html|work=kicker.de|publisher=[[kicker (sports magazine)|kicker Sportmagazin]]|accessdate=22 July 2011}}) is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Sinsheim]], [[Baden-Württemberg]], [[Germany]]. It is used mostly for [[association football|football]] matches and hosts the home matches of [[TSG 1899 Hoffenheim|1899 Hoffenheim]]. The stadium has a capacity of 30,150 people.{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/womensworldcup/destination/cities/city=5990/index.html|title=Women's World Cup Germany 2011 – Sinsheim|work=[[FIFA]]|accessdate=1 February 2009}} It replaced TSG 1899 Hoffenheim's former ground, the [[Dietmar-Hopp-Stadion]]. The stadium is the largest in the [[Rhine-Neckar]] metropolitan area, although it is situated in a town with only 36,000 inhabitants. The first competitive match was played on 31 January 2009 against [[FC Energie Cottbus]], and ended in a 2–0 win for Hoffenheim.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7861712.stm|title=New home for German giant-killers|work=[[BBC News]]|date=30 January 2009|accessdate=1 February 2009}} The stadium hosted international matches at the [[2011 FIFA Women's World Cup]]. The Rhein-Neckar-Arena will host the "2017 DEL Winter Game", an outdoor [[ice hockey]] game between [[Adler Mannheim]] and the [[Schwenninger Wild Wings|Schwenningen Wild Wings]] on 7 January 2017. ==International Soccer Matches== {| class="wikitable" ! Date !! Competition!! Team !! Res !! Team !! Crowd |- | 9 Sep 2018 | International Friendly | {{fb|GER}} | align=center |2-1 | {{fb|PER}} | 25,494 |} == Gallery == File:Sinsheim Rhein-Neckar-Arena.JPG File:Stadion Rhein-Neckar-Arena Sinsheim.JPG File:090103 RheinNeckarArena.JPG == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100804071401/http://www.rheinneckararena.de/ Stadium information and photos] {{de icon}} * [http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=b180740c37731088b9fb03ec86550c5a 3D model of the Rhein-Neckar-Arena] * [http://www.tsg-hoffenheim.de/4news.php?d%5Babteilung%5D=Das%20neue%20Stadion&d%5Bnr%5D=1771&d%5Bvolltextsuche%5D=&ueberschrift=Das+Stadion+-++ein+St%26uuml%3Bck+Zukunft+des+Clubs Stadium plans from club website] {{de icon}} * [http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/europe/germany/baden_wurttemberg/sinsheim_rhein_neckar.shtml World Stadiums] {{TSG 1899 Hoffenheim}} {{Bundesliga venues}} {{2011 FIFA Women's World Cup stadiums}} [[Category:Football venues in Germany]] [[Category:Sports venues in Baden-Württemberg]] [[Category:TSG 1899 Hoffenheim]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Germany]] [[Category:2011 FIFA Women's World Cup]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Rhein-Neckar-Kreis]] [[Category:2009 establishments in Germany]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2009]]

revision.text:
<!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image:230px-KACStade.jpg|thumb|230px]] -->
'''Stade Municipal''' is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Kenitra]], [[Morocco]] which has been inaugurated in 1941. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and is the home stadium of [[KAC Kenitra]].  The stadium has a capacity of 15,000 people, and is currently in renovation. After the renovation the stadium will have a seating capacity between 30,000 and 40,000.<ref>[http://stadiumdb.com/stadiums/mar/stade_municipal_de_kenitra StadiumDB]</ref>

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} [[File:StamfordMuseum Bull run memorial jug.jpg|thumb|upright|right|A jug commemorates Ann Blades - a Stamford bull runner in 1792]]
The '''Stamford bull run''', or the '''bull-running in Stamford''', was a [[bull-running]] and [[bull-baiting]] event held on [[Brice of Tours|St Brice]]'s Day (13 November) in the English town of [[Stamford, Lincolnshire]], for almost 700 years, until it was ended in 1839.<ref name="Chambers 1864">{{cite book |title=Chambers Book of Days |first=Robert |last=Chambers |author-link=Robert Chambers (publisher, born 1802) |chapter=November 13. The Stamford Bull-running |work=[[Chambers Book of Days|The Book of Days: A Miscellany of Popular Antiquities in connection with the Calendar]] |date=1864 |volume=II |publisher=W. & R. Chambers Ltd. |page=575 |chapter-url= https://books.google.com/books?id=VEcJAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA575&dq=Book+of+Days+Chambers+bulls+stamford&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiT0J-d4a_cAhWnBjQIHRfdBBoQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=Book%20of%20Days%20Chambers%20bulls%20stamford&f=false |via=Google Books |access-date=21 July 2018}}</ref> The custom dated from the time of [[John of England|King John]]. A 1996 ''Journal of Popular Culture'' paper refers to the bull run as a [[festival]], in the academic sense of "the broader context of the medieval if not aboriginal festival calendar",<ref name="Walsh">{{cite journal |url= http://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/2027.42/73551/1/j.0022-3840.1996.00233.x.pdf |title=November Bull-running in Stamford, Lincolnshire" |first=Martin W. |last=Walsh |work=Journal of Popular Culture |date=Summer 1996 |doi=10.1111/j.0022-3840.1996.00233.x}}</ref> though works written during and shortly after the activity's later years variously describe it as a "riotous custom", a "hunt", an "old-fashioned, manly, English sport", an "ancient amusement", and – towards its end – an "illegal and disgraceful ... proceeding".<ref name="Chambers 1864" /><ref name="Strutt 1801">{{cite book |title=The Sports and Pastimes of the People of England: From the Earliest Period, Including the Rural and Domestic Recreations, May Games, Mummeries, Pageants, Processions and Pompous Spectacles |first1=Joseph |last1=Strutt |author-link=Joseph Strutt (engraver and antiquary) |editor-first=J. Charles |editor-last=Cox |edition=Enlarged and Corrected |date=1903 |orig-year=1801 |chapter=Performing Animals |page=209 |chapter-url= https://books.google.com/books?id=eJwSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA209&dq=Book+of+Days+Chambers+bulls+stamford&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiT0J-d4a_cAhWnBjQIHRfdBBoQ6AEIMzAC#v=onepage&q=Book%20of%20Days%20Chambers%20bulls%20stamford&f=false |via=Google Books |access-date=21 July 2018}}</ref>
At least one other such regular event survived into fairly modern times, the annual 15 August '''[[Tutbury]] bull-running'''<!--Do not de-boldface this; it redirects here.--> in [[Staffordshire]], which was brought to an end in 1788, the year suppression of the Stamford run also began.<ref name="Strutt 1801" /> Other such events had also been held in earlier times in [[Axbridge]], [[Canterbury]], [[Wokingham]], and [[Wisbech]] {{crossref|(see [[Bull running]] for an overview)}}.
==Origins== According to local tradition, the origin of the Stamford custom dated from the time of [[John, King of England|King John]] (1199 - 1216) when [[William de Warenne, 5th Earl of Surrey]], standing on the battlements of the castle, saw two bulls fighting in the meadow beneath. Some butchers came to part the combatants and one of the bulls ran into the town, causing a great uproar. The earl, mounting his horse, rode after the animal, and enjoyed the sport so much, that he gave the meadow in which the fight began to the butchers of Stamford on condition that they should provide a bull, to be run in the town every 13 November, forever after.<ref name="Walsh" /> The town of Stamford acquired common rights in the grassy floodplain next to the [[River Welland]], which until the last century was known as Bull-meadow, and today just as the Meadows.
Similarly, the [[Tutbury]] run had dubious legendary noble associations, in that case to the 14th-century figure [[John of Gaunt|John of Gaunt, 1st Duke of Lancaster]]
==The event== The ringing of [[St Mary's Church, Stamford|St Mary’s Church]] bells at 10.45 am opened the event, announcing the closing and boarding of shops and the barricading of the street with carts and wagons. By 11 am crowds gathered and the bull was released, baited by the cheering of the crowd, and (among other things) a man who would roll towards it in a barrel. It was then chased through the main street and down to Bull-meadow or into the River Welland. It was caught, killed, and butchered. Its meat was provided to the poor and as such the custom by the 1700s was supported as a charity by donations.
Seventeenth-century historians described how the bull was chased and tormented for the day before being driven to Bull-meadow and slaughtered. "Its flesh [was] sold at a low rate to the people, who finished the day's amusement with a supper of bull-beef."<ref name="Chambers 1864" />
==Suppression and end== [[File:StamfordMuseum Bull Run Last.jpg|thumb|A painting showing the [[5th Dragoon Guards]] heading down the [[Great North Road (Great Britain)|Great North Road]] to suppress the bull run in 1839]] Such an event was a time of drunken disorder. The custom was periodically suppressed and eventually ended in the 19th century. The bull-running in Tutbury, which was more violent and included mutilation of the bull, and involved folk from [[Staffordshire]], [[Derbyshire]], and [[Devonshire]], was ended by the [[Duke of Devonshire]] in 1788.<ref name="Strutt 1801" /> The same year, an unsuccessful attempt (the first recorded) was made to stop the Stamford event.<ref name="Strutt 1801" />
The bull-running in Stamford was the subject of an 1833 campaign by the [[Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals]]. Some Stamford residents defended their ancient custom as a "traditional, manly, English sport; inspiring courage, agility and presence of mind under danger." Its defenders argued that it was less cruel and dangerous than fox hunting, and one local newspaper asked "Who or what is this London Society that, usurping the place of constituted authorities, presumes to interfere with our ancient amusement?"<ref name="Chambers 1864" /> A rather noncommittal [[riot]] trial in 1836 tried only five men, and convicted a mere three; this inspired the town to plan an even bigger event for the next year.<ref name="Chambers 1864" /> The mayor of Stamford – at the direction of and with the support of the [[Home Secretary]] – used 200 newly sworn-in [[Special constabulary|special constables]], some military troops, and police brought in from outside, to stop the bull-run of 1837, but it happened anyway. The bull and the people ran through the security line, a riot ensued, and in the end no one was killed (not even the bull, which turned out to have been supplied by or stolen from a local lord, discreetly unnamed in contemporary reports).<ref name="Chambers 1864" />
The last bull-run of Stamford was in 1839, in the face of an even larger force of soldiers and constables – some of the latter of whom smuggled the bull in themselves. The run was short, with the bull being captured by the peace-keeping forces quickly and without reported serious incident.<ref name="Chambers 1864" /> Because the townsfolk were forced to bear the cost of this militia presence for several years in a row, they agreed to stop the practice on their own henceforth, and kept their word.<ref name="Chambers 1864" /> The last known witness of the bull-running was James Fuller Scholes who spoke of it in a newspaper interview in 1928 before his 94th birthday:<ref>{{cite web |title=Stamford & District News (Closed 1942) |url=http://www.netcomuk.co.uk/~dscholes/5034.html |access-date=18 August 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222034309/http://www.netcomuk.co.uk/~dscholes/5034.html |archive-date=22 February 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Interview, 20 August 1928.</ref> {{quote|I am the only Stamford man living who can remember the bull-running in the streets of the town. I can remember my mother showing me the bull and the horses and men and dogs that chased it. She kept the St Peter's Street – the building that was formerly the Chequers Inn at that time and she showed me the bull-running sport from a bedroom window. I was only four years old then, but I can clearly remember it all. The end of St Peter's Street (where it was joined by Rutland Terrace) was blocked by two farm wagons, and I saw the bull come to the end of the street and return again.}}
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Website | name = The Classical | logo = The Classical logo.jpg | logocaption = Site logo, designed by Jacob Weinstein.<ref name="punk" /> | url = [http://www.theclassical.org/ theclassical.org] | type = [[Sports]], [[current events]], longform | language = [[English language|English]] | author = [[Bethlehem Shoals]], Eric Freeman, David Roth <ref name="grantland">{{cite web|author=Noah Davis |url=http://articles.businessinsider.com/2011-08-15/tech/30064748_1_new-site-sports-outlet-sports-illustrated |title=The Anti-Grantland: The Rest Of The Best In Sportswriting Are Starting A New Site |publisher=Business Insider |date=2011-08-15 |accessdate=2013-01-30}}</ref> | launch date = 2011 <ref name="columbia">{{cite web|author=Bethlehem Shoals |url=http://www.cjr.org/the_news_frontier/a_diy_version_of_a_large-scale_project.php |title=A DIY Version of a Large-Scale Project |publisher=Columbia Journalism Review |date=2011-12-05 |accessdate=2013-01-30}}</ref> | current status = Active }} '''The Classical''' is a sports website featuring long-form sports articles. Described as the sports equivalent of [[The Awl]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Dylan Stableford |url=https://news.yahoo.com/blogs/cutline/classical-looks-kickstart-awl-inspired-sports-215111183.html |title=The Classical looks to kickstart Awl-inspired sports site |publisher=Yahoo |date=2011-08-16 |accessdate=2013-01-30}}</ref> the site was launched in December 2011 by several members of the basketball blog ''FreeDarko'', including [[Bethlehem Shoals]] and Eric Freeman, and features other writers such as David Roth, Eric Nusbaum, [[Tom Scharpling]], Tim Marchman and [[Lang Whitaker]].<ref name="kickstarter">{{cite web|url=http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/101341727/the-classical |title=The Classical by The Classical |publisher=Kickstarter |date=2011-08-15 |accessdate=2013-01-30}}</ref>
==History== In August 2011, it was announced that Shoals and others would be launching a sports website featuring a prominent collection of writers that had written for Sports Illustrated, ESPN, The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, The Nation, Slate, Deadspin, GQ and other publications.<ref name="kickstarter" /> A [[Kickstarter]] page was established by the site's founders, and $50,000 were raised to help maintain the site for its first year.<ref name="kickstarter" /> The Classical launched in December 2011.<ref name="columbia" />
The site's approach to long-form sports writing instantly drew comparisons to Grantland,<ref name="columbia" /><ref>{{cite web|author=Jack Dickey |url=http://deadspin.com/5830909/a-gaggle-of-clever-sportswriters-is-starting-a-long+form-web-concern |title=A Gaggle Of Clever Sportswriters Is Starting A Long-Form Web Concern |publisher=Deadspin |date=2011-08-15 |accessdate=2013-01-30}}</ref> the ESPN-funded website that had been launched by [[Bill Simmons]] the year before.
On the site's Kickstarter page,<ref name="kickstarter" /> the founders of The Classical wrote that the intention of the site was to create something completely original, stating: "We will make no attempt to be comprehensive, or even to offer a reliable guide to the world of sport at a given moment. We will not try to be a smarter version of what you can find elsewhere. Instead, The Classical will be a running, wide-ranging conversation between us and our readers about baseball, basketball, soccer, football and fighting, and about things that aren't sports, too. Our model in this regard is The Awl, a site for which many of us have written and which all of us love."
==Name== The name of the site is in reference to the first track of the 1982 album [[Hex Enduction Hour]], by the English post-punk band [[The Fall (band)|The Fall]].<ref name="punk">{{cite web|author=Kat Stoeffel |url=http://observer.com/2011/08/the-classical-will-publish-post-punk-sports-journalism-if-we-kickstart-them/ |title=The Classical Will Publish Post-Punk Sports Journalism... If We Kickstart Them |publisher=The New York Observer |date=2011-08-16 |accessdate=2013-01-30}}</ref> Pete Beatty, one of the site's founders, said the name was appropriate since "it is probably fair to describe The Classical as post-punk sports journalism."<ref name="punk" />
==References== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://theclassical.org/ Official website]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Tiszaligeti Stadion | image = Tiszaligeti stadion.jpg | image_size = 300px | location = [[Szolnok]], [[Hungary]] | coordinates = {{Coord|47|10|5|N|20|11|59|E|display=title}} | broke_ground = | opened = | renovated = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Szolnoki MÁV FC]] | seating_capacity = 4,000 }} '''Tiszaligeti Stadion''', is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Szolnok]], [[Hungary]]. It is mainly used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and hosts the home matches of [[Szolnoki MÁV FC]] of the [[Nemzeti Bajnokság I]]. The stadium has a capacity of 4,000 spectators.<ref>http://www.szolnokimavfc.hu/klub/informaciok.html Club Website</ref>

{{flagIPC|EUN}} (1992) }} 30 athletes (25 men and 5 women) from '''[[Ukraine]]''' competed at the '''[[1996 Summer Paralympics]]''' in [[Atlanta]], [[United States]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.paralympic.org/Athletes/Results |title=Atlanta 1996 Paralympic Games: Ukraine |accessdate=2012-08-27 |work=paralympic.org}} ==Medallists== {| class="wikitable" |- !style="width:6em"| Medal !style="width:10em"| Name !style="width:7em"| Sport !style="width:10em"| Event |- | {{gold medal}} || [[Vasyl Lishchynskyi]] || [[Athletics at the 1996 Summer Paralympics|Athletics]] || Men's shot put F11 |- | {{silver medal}} || [[Vasyl Lishchynskyi]] || [[Athletics at the 1996 Summer Paralympics|Athletics]] || Men's discus F11 |- | {{silver medal}} || [[Olena Akopyan]] || [[Swimming at the 1996 Summer Paralympics|Swimming]] || Women's 50m freestyle S5 |- | {{silver medal}} || [[Olena Akopyan]] || [[Swimming at the 1996 Summer Paralympics|Swimming]] || Women's 100m freestyle S5 |- | {{silver medal}} || [[Olena Akopyan]] || [[Swimming at the 1996 Summer Paralympics|Swimming]] || Women's 200m freestyle S5 |- | {{bronze medal}} || [[Igor Gorbenko]] || [[Athletics at the 1996 Summer Paralympics|Athletics]] || Men's triple jump F11 |- | {{bronze medal}} || [[Yuriy Andryushin]] || [[Swimming at the 1996 Summer Paralympics|Swimming]] || Men's 100m freestyle S7 |} ==See also== *[[Ukraine at the Paralympics]] *[[Ukraine at the 1996 Summer Olympics]] == References == {{reflist}} {{NPCin1996SummerParalympics}} [[Category:Nations at the 1996 Summer Paralympics]] [[Category:Ukraine at the Paralympics|1996]] [[Category:1996 in Ukrainian sport|Summer Paralympics]] {{1996-Paralympics-stub}} {{Ukraine-sport-stub}}

[[File:Eagle River Stadium Wisconsin Hockey Hall of Fame.jpg|thumb|right|The Wisconsin Hockey Hall of Fame at the [[Eagle River Stadium]].]] The '''Wisconsin Hockey [[Hall of Fame]]''' which is located in [[Eagle River, Wisconsin]], was founded in 1975 and is housed in the [[Eagle River Stadium|Eagle River Sports Arena]]. The hall was established to honor outstanding individuals responsible for the development, growth and success of amateur [[ice hockey]] in the State of [[Wisconsin]].
The Hall is open daily from 9:00 am to 5:00 pm. During the season it opens and closes when the rink does which is usually before 9:00 am and after 5:00 pm.
==Notable Inductees== * [[Jeff Sauer]] - 2004 * [[Craig Ludwig]] - 2002 * [[Mark Johnson (hockey player)|Mark Johnson]] - 2001 * [[Bob Suter]] - 2001 * [[John Mayasich]] - 1989 * [[Bob Johnson (ice hockey b. 1931)|Bob Johnson]]- 1987
==See also== *[[United States Hockey Hall of Fame]] *[[Wisconsin Athletic Hall of Fame|Wisconsin Athletic Walk of Fame]]
